dialogue_turns.speaker: People think central banks are pulling back on a massive scale, but actually, the 2.2 trillion dollars in liquidity being withdrawn is just a pittance compared to U.S. output.
dialogue_turns.text: People think central banks are pulling back on a massive scale, but actually, the 2.2 trillion dollars in liquidity being withdrawn is just a pittance compared to U.S. output.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: People think central banks are pulling back on a massive scale, but actually, the two point two trillion dollars in liquidity being withdrawn is just a pittance compared to U.S. output.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The roughly $22 trillion of liquidity the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of Japan and Bank of England are pumping into financial systems matches the size of annual U.S. output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's wild that this comes right as places like China and Brazil are seeing huge new demand, creating this unprecedented boom.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's wild that this comes right as places like China and Brazil are seeing huge new demand, creating this unprecedented boom.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That may be just the start, as the odds of new outbreaks threaten to pulverize demand from China to Brazil.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and then you've got Japan, which has had remarkable growth for decades now, but their situation is so different from the Fed or ECB approach.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and then you've got Japan, which has had remarkable growth for decades now, but their situation is so different from the Fed or E C B approach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As if often the case in gloomy economic moments, attention turns to Japan, where deflation has been the reality for two decades now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like Governor Haruhiko Kuroda at the BOJ has been trying to fight deflation since 2013, but now inflation's creeping back up anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like Governor Haruhiko Kuroda at the B O J has been trying to fight deflation since twenty thirteen, but now inflation's creeping back up anyway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though the BOJ made some progress since 2013 generating upward price pressures, the deflationary mindset Governor Haruhiko Kuroda sought to change is reasserting itself. Whats more, as gross domestic product, factory activity and retail sales crater, disinflationary forces may be intensifying.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's interesting 'cause Japan really pioneered fiscal tightening back in 1999, which is the total opposite of what the U.S. and Europe are doing now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's interesting 'cause Japan really pioneered fiscal tightening back in nineteen ninety nine, which is the total opposite of what the U.S. and Europe are doing now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 1999, zero interest rates have been the norm in Japan, which pioneered quantitative easing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it seems like their strategy of austere monetary easing has actually made things better long-term, even if it's counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it seems like their strategy of austere monetary easing has actually made things better long-term, even if it's counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, as Japan shows, audacious monetary easing tends to make things worst in the longer run.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got this inequality problem—like, in Japan, QE policies would apparently harm the asset-owning class, which is why they're hesitant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got this inequality problem-like, in Japan, Q E policies would apparently harm the asset-owning class, which is why they're hesitant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though rising competition from China is depressing wages, QE policies enriched the land- and asset-owning class at the expense of the masses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government is cutting over 2 trillion in spending to curb confidence, which sounds extreme but might be a stabilizer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government is cutting over two trillion in spending to curb confidence, which sounds extreme but might be a stabilizer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fans of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe point out that Tokyo is ginning up more than $2 trillion of spending, more than 40% of GDP, to restore confidence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's led to some positive outcomes, like companies hoarding less cash—it plummeted to 450 billion dollars last quarter, which is only 5% of GDP.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's led to some positive outcomes, like companies hoarding less cash-it plummeted to four hundred fifty billion dollars last quarter, which is only five percent of G D P.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the first quarter, for example, cash hoarding among companies rose to $4.5 trillion, an eye-popping 89% of GDP.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So inflation in Japan just isn't about the amount of money in circulation; it's about how it's used, and they've built up this confidence in lending and borrowing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So inflation in Japan just isn't about the amount of money in circulation; it's about how it's used, and they've built up this confidence in lending and borrowing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because banks, companies and households lack confidence about the future, little lending and borrowing takes place.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which kinda puts pressure on CEOs to relax competitive games and focus on real revenue and profit expansion instead of just relying on easy money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which kinda puts pressure on CEOs to relax competitive games and focus on real revenue and profit expansion instead of just relying on easy money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All that free money took the onus off CEOs to raise their competitive games. Companies came to depend on loans to stay afloat, while dwindling profits make it hard to cover debt payments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you look at the U.S. and Europe, where central banks are acting like a 22 trillion dollar ATM, and it might actually decrease productivity and widen inequality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you look at the U.S. and Europe, where central banks are acting like a twenty two trillion dollar A T M, and it might actually decrease productivity and widen inequality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S., eurozone and U.K. are on a similar trajectory as the central banks play the role of mere ATMsa $22 trillion ATM among just the G4 monetary authorities. All that largess wont increase Americas productivity or narrow the rich-poor divide.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, all that stimulus could halt wealth from trickling up to middle- and lower-income households, which is the opposite of what happened after 2008 in the U.S.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, all that stimulus could halt wealth from trickling up to middle- and lower-income households, which is the opposite of what happened after two thousand eight in the U.S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But with no vibrant export destination and few true reformers in government, all that cash is likely to accelerate the trickling up of wealth away from middle- and lower-income households.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So in a way, Japan's scarcity approach might be accelerating global economic risks, but it's also revitalizing their own economy from within.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So in a way, Japan's scarcity approach might be accelerating global economic risks, but it's also revitalizing their own economy from within.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over time, though, its led to the zombie-fication of so much of Japans entire economy. All that free money took the onus off CEOs to raise their competitive games.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a huge gamble, but for them, austere money seems to be paying off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a huge gamble, but for them, austere money seems to be paying off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, as Japan shows, audacious monetary easing tends to make things worst in the longer run. Free money is coming at a huge cost.

artist_script:
People think central banks are pulling back on a massive scale, but actually, the 2.2 trillion dollars in liquidity being withdrawn is just a pittance compared to U.S. output.
HostB: Yeah, and it's wild that this comes right as places like China and Brazil are seeing huge new demand, creating this unprecedented boom.
HostA: Exactly, and then you've got Japan, which has had remarkable growth for decades now, but their situation is so different from the Fed or ECB approach.
HostB: Right, like Governor Haruhiko Kuroda at the BOJ has been trying to fight deflation since 2013, but now inflation's creeping back up anyway.
HostA: And it's interesting 'cause Japan really pioneered fiscal tightening back in 1999, which is the total opposite of what the U.S. and Europe are doing now.
HostB: Yeah, and it seems like their strategy of austere monetary easing has actually made things better long-term, even if it's counterintuitive.
HostA: But then you've got this inequality problem—like, in Japan, QE policies would apparently harm the asset-owning class, which is why they're hesitant.
HostB: Meanwhile, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s government is cutting over 2 trillion in spending to curb confidence, which sounds extreme but might be a stabilizer.
HostA: And it's led to some positive outcomes, like companies hoarding less cash—it plummeted to 450 billion dollars last quarter, which is only 5% of GDP.
HostB: So inflation in Japan just isn't about the amount of money in circulation; it's about how it's used, and they've built up this confidence in lending and borrowing.
HostA: Which kinda puts pressure on CEOs to relax competitive games and focus on real revenue and profit expansion instead of just relying on easy money.
HostB: But then you look at the U.S. and Europe, where central banks are acting like a 22 trillion dollar ATM, and it might actually decrease productivity and widen inequality.
HostA: Yeah, all that stimulus could halt wealth from trickling up to middle- and lower-income households, which is the opposite of what happened after 2008 in the U.S.
HostB: So in a way, Japan’s scarcity approach might be accelerating global economic risks, but it's also revitalizing their own economy from within.
HostA: It's a huge gamble, but for them, austere money seems to be paying off.
